facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 62 and 1672 of 1969 were filed

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 62 and 1672 of 1969.

facts.text: Appeals from judgments and orders dated May 17, 1968 of Allahabad High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 310 and 627 of 1968

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgments and orders dated May 17, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 310 and 627 of 1968.
The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hegde, J.
These are appeals by certificate.
The appellants are dealers in Rab.

facts.text: Appellants levied purchase tax on dealings in Rab as per notification issued by Government under s. 3-D(1) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: In respect of their dealings in Rab, they have been levied purchase tax as per the notification issued by the Government under s. 3 D 1 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellants challenging validity of levy on grounds of excessive delegation of power under s. 3-D(1)

anchor.surface_text: the power delegated to the executive under S. 3-D 1 is excessive and as such bad in law

facts.text: Appellants contending s. 3-D infringes Art. 14 by discriminating between registered dealers purchasing through licensed dealers and other dealers

anchor.surface_text: Section 3-D infringes Art. 14 of the Constitution in as much as it discriminates between the registered dealers who purchase through the agency of licensed dealers and the registered dealers who purchase through other dealers

facts.text: Allahabad High Court repelled both contentions of appellants

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has repelled both the above contentions.

facts.text: High Court concluded power conferred on State Government under s. 3-D is valid

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has come to the conclusion that the power conferred on the State Government under s. 3-D is a valid power.

facts.text: High Court held conferment of power to fix rate of tax within limits is not impermissible

anchor.surface_text: It opined that the conferment of power on the executive to fix the rate of tax within the limits laid down in the section is not impermissible.

facts.text: High Court held s. 3-D not hit by Art. 14

anchor.surface_text: Further it held that the section is not hit by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Section 3-D(1) provides for tax on turnover of first purchases at rates notified by State Government not exceeding two paisa per rupee for foodgrains and five paisa for other goods

anchor.surface_text: Except as provided in sub-section (2), there shall be levied and paid, for each assessment year or part thereof, a tax on the turnover... five paisa per rupee in the case of other goods and with effect from such date, as may, from time to time, be notified by the State Government in this behalf.

facts.text: Explanation to s. 3-D deems registered dealer through licensed dealer as first purchaser, otherwise the agent dealer as first purchaser

anchor.surface_text: Explanation.-In the case of a purchase made by a registered dealer through the agency of a licensed dealer, the registered dealer shall be deemed to be the first purchaser, and in every other case of a first purchase, made through the agency of a dealer, the dealer who is the agent shall be deemed to be the first purchaser.

facts.text: Licensed dealers bound to maintain accounts and furnish details to assessing authority

anchor.surface_text: A licensed dealer has to function according to the conditions of his licence. He is bound to maintain true and correct accounts of his day to day transactions Of sales and purchase of goods notified in sub-s. (1) of s. 3-D... furnish to the assessing authority the details...

facts.text: Unlicensed dealers not required to maintain accounts or submit returns

anchor.surface_text: but that would not be the case when purchases are made through dealers who are not licensed. They are not required by law to maintain any accounts or submit any returns.
the vires of s. 3-D 1  of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948  to be hereinafter referred to as the Act .

concepts.interpretation: Section 3-D does not violate Art. 14 as classification between licensed and unlicensed dealers is reasonable to prevent tax evasion; power of classification greater under fiscal laws.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgments and orders dated May 17, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 310 and 627 of 1968

issues.text: whether the power delegated to the executive under S. 3-D(1) of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948 is excessive and as such bad in law

anchor.surface_text: that the power delegated to the executive under S. 3-D 1  is excessive and as such bad in law

issues.text: whether Section 3-D of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948 infringes Article 14 of the Constitution in as much as it discriminates between the registered dealers who purchase through the agency of licensed dealers and the registered dealers who purchase through other dealers

anchor.surface_text: Section 3-D infringes Art. 14 of the Constitution in as much as it discriminates between the registered dealers who purchase through the agency of licensed dealers and the registered dealers who purchase through other dealers,

arguments.court_reasoning: Legislature laid down policy, guidelines, and upper limits; precedents permit delegation of tax rate fixing with limits; flexible power necessary in modern economy

arguments.claim: maximum rate fixed under S. 3-D is unreasonably high

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention of Mr. Goyal, learned Counsel for the appellant that the maximum rate fixed under S. 3-D is unreasonably high.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e under the various sales tax laws in force in this companyntry, it cannot be said that the power delegated to the executive is excessive. In Devi Das

arguments.court_reasoning: No material on record to conclude unreasonableness

arguments.claim: Section 3-D infringes Art. 14 of the Constitution in as much as it discriminates between the registered dealers who purchase through the agency of licensed dealers and the registered dealers who purchase through other dealers

anchor.surface_text: Section 3-D infringes Art. 14 of the Constitution in as much as it discriminates between the registered dealers who purchase through the agency of licensed dealers and the registered dealers who purchase through other dealers,

arguments.court_reasoning: Classification reasonable with rational nexus to preventing tax evasion; licensed dealers required to maintain accounts and furnish details unlike unlicensed; greater classification power under fiscal laws

arguments.claim: no justification for making an agent liable to pay sales tax merely because he is an unlicensed agent; no rational distinction between purchases through licensed and unlicensed dealers

anchor.surface_text: He urged that there was no justification for making an agent liable to pay sale tax merely because he is an unlicensed agent. According to him there is no rational distinction between the purchases made through licensed dealers and those made through unlicensed dealers.

arguments.court_reasoning: Licensed dealers bound to maintain accounts and submit returns enabling tax authorities to track; unlicensed do not, increasing evasion risk; burden ultimately on principal

arguments.claim: power conferred on State Government under s. 3-D is a valid power; conferment to fix rate within limits not impermissible

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has come to the conclusion that the power conferred on the State Government under s. 3-D is a valid power. It opined that the conferment of power on the executive to fix the rate of tax within the limits laid down in the section is not impermissible.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: be a flexible power. It must be capable of being modulated to meet the exigencies of the situation. In a Cabinet form of Government, the executive is

arguments.court_reasoning: SC agrees, elaborates on policy, guidelines, precedents

arguments.claim: section is not hit by Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Further it held that the section is not hit by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC upholds, provides reasoning on reasonable classification

arguments.claim: power to fix rate of tax is legislative but delegable if legislature lays down policy and guidelines

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the power to fix the rate of a tax is a legislative power but if the legislature lays down the legislative policy and provides the necessary guidelines, that power can be delegated to the executive.

arguments.claim: in modern society taxation instrument of planning requiring flexible delegable power

anchor.surface_text: Though a tax is levied primarily for the purpose of gathering revenue... In a modern society taxation is an instrument of planning. It can be used to achieve the economic and social goals of the State. For that reason the power to tax must be a flexible power.

arguments.claim: not unconstitutional to delegate details like rate of tax to executive (citing State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley)

anchor.surface_text: In State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. Madras Ltd. this Court observed Now, the authorities are clear that it is not unconstitutional for the legislature to leave it to the executive to determine details relating to the working of taxation laws, such as the selection of persons on whom the tax is to be levied, the rate at which it is to be charged in respect of different classes of goods and the like.

arguments.claim: open to legislature to delegate fixing rate if reasonable upper limit prescribed (citing Devi Dass Gopal Krishnan)

anchor.surface_text: In Devi Dass Gopal Krishnan and ors. v. The State of Punjab and ors this Court ruled that it is open to the legislature to delegate the power of fixing the rate of purchase tax or sales tax if the legislature prescribes a reasonable upper limit.

arguments.claim: power delegated not excessive considering legislative practice and rates in sales tax laws

anchor.surface_text: Taking into consideration the legislative practice in this country and the rate of tax levied or leviable under the various sales tax laws in force in this country, it cannot be said that the power delegated to the executive is excessive.

arguments.claim: rule of discrimination does not rule out classification; power of classification larger under fiscal law

anchor.surface_text: The rule of discrimination does not rule out classification. The power of classification under a fiscal law is larger than in the case of other laws.

arguments.claim: classification between licensed and unlicensed dealers has rational nexus to preventing tax evasion

holdings.text: the power delegated to the executive under S. 3-D(1) is not excessive

anchor.surface_text: country, it cannot be said that the power delegated to the executive is excessive. In Devi Dass Gopal Krishnan and ors. v. The State of Punjab and ors

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature laid down policy, guidelines, and upper limits on rates; consistent with precedents (Gannon Dunkerley, Devi Dass) permitting delegation for tax details and rate-fixing within limits; flexible power needed for modern taxation planning.

holdings.text: the maximum rate fixed under S. 3-D is not unreasonably high
holdings.reasoning_summary: No material on record to support unreasonableness; rates consistent with legislative practice in sales tax laws across country.

holdings.text: the power to fix the rate of a tax is a legislative power but if the legislature lays down the legislative policy and provides the necessary guidelines, that power can be delegated to the executive

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the power to fix the rate of a tax is a legislative power but if the legislature lays down the legislative policy and provides the necessary guidelines,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established doctrine allowing delegation in taxation for administrative convenience and flexibility to meet economic goals; legislatures lack time and information for details.

holdings.text: s. 3-D is not ultra vires Art. 14 of the Constitution
holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification between licensed and unlicensed dealers reasonable and has rational nexus to preventing tax evasion, as licensed dealers maintain accounts and submit returns while unlicensed do not; greater latitude for classification in fiscal laws.

holdings.text: there was nothing wrong in the legislature making a classification between licensed dealers and dealers who are not licensed
holdings.reasoning_summary: Licensed dealers accountable via licence conditions enabling tax tracking; unlicensed increase evasion risk; burden ultimately on principal; power of classification larger under fiscal statutes.

holdings.text: The rule of discrimination does not rule out classification. The power of classification under a fiscal law is larger than in the case of other laws.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 14 permits reasonable classification with nexus to object; enhanced in taxation to combat evasion.
